column4: Sorry for the stupid question, but I downloaded Adobe 7 in tar.gz format. I extracted it to /home/weiers/AdobeReader and now I want to run the INSTALL script. How do I do that?
you need to open a terminal and go to that directory
... I did that
is there no README or INSTALL document in it?
are you ./running ./the ./INSTALL?
then chmod +x <install script>
sorry... I am sure I am just doing something strange
you need to type ./<name of install script>
your commands in linux are in a path
commands not in the path have to be executed in a special way
placing a ./  <which means "right here" in linux> tells the OS to execute that particular thing
even tho its not in the path of commmand
before I came to this forum I saw somewhere that I could have chmod 555 or something... would that have put it into the path permanently.
no it would not

... thanks... I won't take more of your time, but if it type "export PATH=$PATH: ./AdobeReader/ " I would probably have been able to put it there permanently?.... Anyway. I am learning slowly every day... just saw this on the website that made no sense to me before I came here.
depends on where you put that "export PATH" line in
you need w32codecs first
I think I have them because I have been playing them on Totem
gstreamer works pretty good overall

thank you very much for the bash script. It seems I have access to my Fat32 drive, and it mounted my NTFS partion as well, although that one is only read only. Can I now rename the drives to be more descriptive of what I use them for?
see "man fstab"
or symlink the mounted drives into your home folder with names YOU like
I'll play around a bit. This has made my life very simple. I've read the manual pages on chown - but they did not tell me that it does not work on windows drives.
just symlink the drives from /media to your $HOMEDIR and name the symlinks what you want. I use this method
